awd_titl_txt: FRG: Collaborative Research: Non-Smooth Geometry, Spectral Theory, and Data: Learning and Representing Projections of Complex Systems
awd_abstract_narration:
Complex, time-evolving systems are ubiquitous in nature and society, with examples ranging from the Earth's weather and climate, to the function and dynamics of biomolecules, and the behavior of markets and economies. Despite their apparent complexity, many such systems exhibit a form of underlying organized structure (``building blocks''), whose discovery would enhance our ability to understand and predict a wide range of phenomena. The goal of this project is to develop the next generation of mathematical and algorithmic tools that can harness the information content of large datasets acquired from experiments and observations to create coherent representations of complex systems, and use these representations to perform prediction, and ultimately, control. These objectives will be addressed through a novel combination of mathematical techniques, bridging dynamical systems theory and differential geometry with machine learning and data science. The newly developed techniques will be tested and applied in real-world problems through collaboration with domain experts in the areas of climate dynamics, space physics, and condensed matter physics. The project will also contribute to STEM workforce and curricular development through training of students and postdoctoral researchers, and design of multi-disciplinary lecture courses. In particular, this project will support one graduate student at each of the three universities involved.

The modern scientific method is undergoing an evolutionary change wherein large data sets and machine learning algorithms have the potential to outperform classical first-principles approaches for certain complex phenomena.  For these tools to be accepted by the scientific community, a rigorous mathematical framework is required to match the verifiability and quantifiability of the classical modeling approach.  Recently, a new tool called the diffusion forecast has been developed based on provably consistent estimators, which learn the unknown structure of a large class of stochastic dynamical systems on manifolds.  Moreover, the results of many published numerical experiments indicate that this framework can be applied far beyond the restricted context of the current theory.  In particular, the evidence suggests that the consistency proofs can be extended to non-autonomous projections of complex systems, deterministic chaotic systems represented by non-compact operators, non-smooth domains such as fractal attractors, and even generalized tensors on metric-measure spaces. This project will undertake a rigorous mathematical unification of these problems, leading to transformative advances in our ability to model and describe complex systems.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
The proposed project is to develop a mathematically rigorous model-free, data-driven framework for predicting complex dynamical systems, by leveraging the geometrical information encoded in the available training data set and machine learning techniques. The key achievement in this project includes the development of a general closure framework to recover missing dynamical systems for predicting the evolution of the relevant observable, connecting the Mori-Zwanzig formalism, Taken's embedding theory, and supervised learning frameworks. We deduced a theoretical result that allows one to estimate the horizon time for accurate prediction given the size of training data, the complexity of the proposed model, the dimensionality of the learning problem, and the statistical characterization of noisy data. Numerically, we demonstrated the effectiveness of the framework in identifying missing components on various high-dimensional complex dynamical systems that arise in physical modeling, including the barotropic stress models with multiscale interactions that mimic the blocked and unblocked patterns observed in the atmosphere, the nonlinear Schrodinger equation which found many applications in physics such as optics and Bose-Einstein-Condense, the spatiotemporally chaotic Kuramoto-Sivashinsky equation. Another problem studied in this project is to mathematically understand to which extent the invariant (or climatological) statistics of dynamical systems can be estimated by approximate dynamics identified by a machine learning procedure. We deduced mathematical error bounds in the context of learning a class of dynamical systems known as Ito diffusion. We showed that the error bounds of two commonly used metrics that are used in empirical applications, one-time and two-time statistics, depend linearly on the generalization error in learning the drift component of the stochastic differential equations. We also provided concrete error bounds for two popular learning algorithms, kernel-based spectral regression method, and random neural networks. To help practical implementation, we characterized the error bounds in terms of the size of training data, dimension of the dynamical systems, complexity of the hypothesis model, noise amplitude, and temporal discretization.  

To support the goal of this project, we have also developed various technical. They include 1) A novel Bayesian machine learning algorithm for predicting El Nino indices; 2) Deriving parametric closure modeling from a general nonparametric non-Markovian framework; 3) Realizing the proposed framework with novel class of kernel techniques, including the kernel analog forecast and a smoother that is found to be effective for denoising noisy data; 4) An application of the proposed framework to predict statistical responses of homogeneous turbulent dynamical systems under external disturbances. 

 Additionally, we have also pursued several research problems related to (and motivated by the outcomes) of the proposed projects. They include: 1) Adopting nonparametric formulation to the estimation of linear statistical responses of dynamical systems. 2) Extending the diffusion maps algorithm, a nonlinear manifold algorithm, to estimate non-local operators such as the fractional Laplacians. 3) Extending the diffusion maps algorithm to estimate Laplacian on manifolds with boundaries (including the Dirichlet, Neuman, and Robin boundary conditions). 4) Extending the diffusion maps for solving forward elliptic PDEs on unknown manifolds and the corresponding Bayesian elliptic inverse problems.

Through the projects in this award, the PIs have mentored four graduate students (three of these students earned their Ph.D.) and one postdoctoral researcher. The total number of publications resulting from this award includes 13 published peer-reviewed articles, and 1 paper is under review. Beyond these formal publications, the PIs have disseminated the results through various conference and seminar presentations.
